questions.question_text:
The sales table has columns PROD_ID and QUANTITY_SOLD of data type number.

Which two queries execute successfully? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: I AGREE AD
A D is correct

choices.E: SELECT prcd_id FROM sales WHERE quantity_sold > 55000 AND COUNT (*) > 10 GROUP BY prod_id HAVING COUNT(*) > 10;
choices.B: SELECT COUNT(prod_id) FROM sales GROUP BY prod_id WHERE quantity_sold > 55000;
choices.A: SELECT COUNT(prod_id) FROM sales WHERE quantity_sold > 55000 GROUP BY prod_id;
choices.C: SELECT prod_id FROM sales WHERE quantity_sold > 55000 AND COUNT(*) > 10 GROUP BY COUNT(*) > 10;
choices.D: SELECT prod_id FROM sales WHERE quantity_sold > 55000 GROUP BY proa_id HAVING COUNT(*) > 10;

discussion.content: I AGREE AE

Selected Answer: AE
Provided answer are wrong. The base! :-) part VII
A E is the good answers

Selected Answer: AE
The same question as 1z0-071
Question #: 229

choices.B: EXPIRY_DATE cannot be used in arithmetic expressions.
choices.E: PRODUCT_PRICE can be used in an arithmetic expression even if it has no value stored in it.
choices.F: PRODUCT_PRICE contains the value zero by default if no value is assigned to it.
choices.A: PRODUCT_ID can be assigned the PRIMARY KEY constraint.
choices.D: EXPIRY_DATE contains the SYSDATE by default if no date is assigned to it.

discussion.content: I AGRRE AD

Selected Answer: AD
True statements about intervals in Oracle Database 19c:
A. True - INTERVAL DAY TO SECOND columns support fractions of seconds.
D. True - INTERVAL YEAR TO MONTH columns only support monthly intervals within a range of years.
False statements:
B. False - The YEAR field in an INTERVAL YEAR TO MONTH column can be a negative value.
C. False - The value in an INTERVAL DAY TO SECOND column cannot be copied into an INTERVAL YEAR TO MONTH column.
E. False - INTERVAL YEAR TO MONTH columns can include monthly intervals spanning multiple years.
F. False - INTERVAL YEAR TO MONTH columns do not support yearly intervals.

Selected Answer: AF
Provided answer are wrong.

Selected Answer: AF
1z0-071
Question #: 292

choices.E: INTERVAL YEAR TO MONTH columns only support monthly intervals within a single year.
choices.F: INTERVAL YEAR TO MONTH support yearly intervals.
choices.A: INTERVAL DAY TO SECOND columns support fractions of seconds.
choices.C: The value in an INTERVAL DAY TO SECOND column can be copied into an INTERVAL YEAR TO MONTH column.
choices.D: INTERVAL YEAR TO MONTH columns only support monthly intervals within a range of years.
choices.B: The YEAR field in an INTERVAL YEAR TO MONTH column must be a positive value.

questions.question_text: Which two statements are true about INTERVAL data types? (Choose two.)

Examine the description of the EMPLOYEES table:

//IMG//


NLS_DATE_FORMAT is set to DD-MON-YY.

Which query requires explicit data type conversion?

choices.A: SELECT join_date FROM employees WHERE join_date > '10-02-2018';

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A is definitly correct.
Without explicit conversion:
SELECT join_date FROM employees WHERE join_date > '10-02-2020';
ORA-01843: not a valid month

With explicit conversion:
SELECT join_date FROM employees WHERE join_date > TO_DATE('10-02-2020', 'DD-MM-YYYY');
-> Returns correct join_date on my test table.

All other options return a result without explicit conversion.

Tested on livesql.oracle.com
A is correct

what about
Option D?: SELECT SUBSTR(join_date, 1, 2) - 10 FROM employees; This query is attempting to perform a substring operation on a DATE type, which is not valid without first converting the date to a string. Oracle does not support taking substrings directly from DATE data types. The date must be converted to a string using TO_CHAR before SUBSTR can be used. Furthermore, subtracting 10 from a substring of a date does not make sense unless the substring represents a number, which is not the case here since join_date is a date and not a string of numbers. Therefore, explicit conversion is necessary, and the query itself is somewhat nonsensical without additional context or correction. This makes Option D the most clearly incorrect and the one that certainly requires explicit data type conversion to even make sense as a SQL statement.

comments.content:
Let me correct my suggestion, please. Only C is correct. 
Datatype conversion in A does not make the query valid.
SQL> SELECT join_date FROM employees WHERE TO_DATE(join_date,'DD-MM-YYYY') > '10-02-2018';
SELECT join_date FROM employees WHERE TO_DATE(join_date,'DD-MM-YYYY') > '10-02-2018'
 *
ERROR at line 1:
ORA-01843: not a valid month

Only altering session variable NLS_DATE_FORMAT with
ALTER SESSION SET nls_date_format='DD-MM-YY';
makes the A query to return valid response. So thereÂ´s no datatype conversion, just altering session variable, therefore A is false.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
AC is correct.
A returns:
SELECT join_date FROM employees WHERE join_date > '10-02-2018';
SELECT join_date FROM employees WHERE join_date > '10-02-2018'
 *
ERROR at line 1:
ORA-01843: not a valid month

C returns:
SQL> SELECT salary+'120.50' FROM employees;
SELECT salary+'120.50' FROM employees
 *
ERROR at line 1:
ORA-01722: invalid number

Selected Answer: A
Provided answer is wrong! The base! :-) part VIII

C
tested

questions.question_text:
You start your database instance in NOMOUNT state.

Which two actions are performed? (Choose two.)

choices.E: Memory is allocated for the SGA.
choices.B: The consistency of the database is checked.
choices.D: All required background processes are started.
